Scribe is a pen and paper game for two players. Nine mini grids together form one super grid. Draws cannot occur in Scribe. Mark Steere invented Scribe on October 1, 2006.

The two players take turns marking squares, one square per turn, until the entire super grid is filled. Players are not allowed to pass on their turn. On your first turn, you can claim any square on the super grid. The mini grid of your last move is treated as a map. The square you last claimed (marked with a small white dot) points to the mini grid in which you must make your next move. For example, in this screenshot, Red\'s last move was in the upper-right corner of a mini grid, so Red must now play in the upper-right mini grid. If your last move points to a completely filled mini grid, you can make your next move anywhere in the super grid.

Press \"menu\" to see the 19 glyphs of Scribe. Each glyph is worth the number of dots that compose it. For example the J is worth six points. A glyph also represents its own mirror image and rotations. Glyphs appearing as a subset of a larger group don\'t count. When a mini grid is completely filled, the glyph points are tallied and the high score wins.
Blue has four Singles and Red has two Singles. With a score of 4-2, Blue is the winner.
Blue has a Pipe (4 points) and Red has a Double and a Triple (5 points). Red is the winner.
Blue has the House glyph, which is worth 7 points. Red has two Singles for 2 points. Blue wins.
Red has the Pipe glyph, for 4 points. Blue doesn\'t have any glyph at all, so Red wins the mini grid.
